bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, August 11, 1941

div1.p: Lambert informs Truby that he feels better after his stay in Hot Springs, Arkansas. He has discovered the names of the immune nurses who served at Quemados, and asserts that Kelly's book errs in stating that yellow fever was best treated with the aid of trained female nurses. He maintains that Ames was most successful in treating yellow fever when he used male orderlies.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Albert E. Truby, August 11, 1941
div1.opener:
Chicago Aug 11 th
1941
Gen Albert E Truby
Dear Sir
div1.p:
I thank you for your kind
letter and the good wishes it
contained, yes The baths did
me a lot of good, shoulders
hips and back benefited a
lot, right leg which was
brocken years ago and not
properly set did not clear
up as much as I would have
wished it to do, but I have
had a lot of trouble with that
leg for the last six years so I
could not expect it to get well
On arriving home here I
found a letter from Mrs
Gray the lady who wrote to
Mrs Warner, it appears that
Warner is not a number
of The U. S. W. N. and Mrs Gray
being The Sec. of the organization
wanted Warner to join, in
their correspondence Warner
had mentioned the names
of the immunes that worked
with her at quemados and
it was Mrs Gillen and Lottie
book. Warner did not tell her
the names when she first wrote
and asked where they could
be found. It was a satisfaction
to me to know their names
because I know now why
Dr Ames never put them to
work Dr. Ames did not loose
a case at No- 1, he lost 4 of the
first 5 who had yellow fever
at quemados Then he went
back. to using male attendant
and lost only one in more
then 40 cases and that man
had been a drinker. still in
the book Maj. Walter Reed and
yellow fever it states that in
order to obtain the best results
in the treatment of yellow
fever trained female nurses
must be used (page 276)
I think Warner gave Dr Kelly (the
author) that information
Andrus is a little prince as
chearful as if he did not
have a worry in the world
he is blessed with a wonder-
full disposition I did not
know if it would be of any
interest to you to learn the
names of the nurses but when
Mrs Gray sent them I thought
I would forward them
I hope you will pardon
me if I say that I'm very
anxious to read the book
